head.title: Hope and Fear on Social Security

hedline.hl1: Hope and Fear on Social Security

abstract.p: Alan L Fredrick letter, replying to May 29 editorial, suggests raising taxable income base for Social Security beyond the present $76,200

block.p: In ''Campaigning on Social Security'' (editorial, May 29), you suggest that Congress should ''cut benefits and raise taxes modestly.'' But that would burden the least fortunate to further feed the wealthy.

In ''Campaigning on Social Security'' (editorial, May 29), you suggest that Congress should ''cut benefits and raise taxes modestly.'' But that would burden the least fortunate to further feed the wealthy.

The fairest and simplest remedy, if one is truly needed, would be the upward extension of the taxable income base beyond the present $76,200 of wages and salary, to all income; thus, the wealthy would finally pay their fair share. A graduated, progressive Social Security tax is also long overdue. At its flat rate it is among the most regressive broad-based taxes, similar to the regressive sales tax.
ALAN L. FREDRICK Little Neck, Queens, May 29, 2000
